results.title: Life in a fishing village
results.brief_description: Scenes in the harbour and town of Gravarna, a fishing village on the west coast of Sweden, with emphasis on the importance of the fishing fleet to the activities of the entire village, and the part played by this community in the European fishing industry. Follows a young boy at school, at work and at play.

results.title: Life in a drop of water
results.brief_description: Presents, by means of microcinematography, the fundamental life processes of nutrition, locomotion, reaction, and reproduction of the simplest plant and animal forms - the algae, amoeba, spirogyra, vulvox, paramecia, botacella, stentor, hydra and various rotapers.

results.title: Life history of the mosquito aedes aegypti: carrier of yellow fever
results.brief_description: Presents the stages of growth during metamorphosis. From egg, lava, pupa and then mosquito. Silent film - no commentary.

results.title: Life from the sea
results.brief_description: To ensure a continuing supply of marine products, which make up to 57% of animal protein in the Japanese diet, marine resources must be conserved and protected. Surveys of fishing grounds are made; there are regulations regarding season, fish and equipment; hatcheries for salmon and the cultivation of fish, seaweed and shellfish are increasing; a fishing high school gives special training; and a high standard of automation and hygiene prevails throughout the industry.

results.title: Life forms
results.creator_credit: George Wallace-Crabbe, Lucy MacLaren, Film Victoria and LM Films Pty Ltd
results.brief_description: Emily, an adolescent girl lives with her mother and father in a large house in the country. Her father Gerald, who’s increasingly away on work trips, tests the relationship with his wife Mel when he’s discovered to be having an affair. As Emily is thrust into the throes of puberty, she’s faced with the inevitability of change as she witnesses the not so idyllic relationship of her parents seen for the first time with adult eyes. Just when things were getting too grown-up an accident occurs that cements Emily’s loss of innocence. Cast includes: Natasha Pincus, Anna Maria Monticelli, Gerard Kennedy, Robert Menzies and Jo Kennedy.

results.title: Life begins
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and ERPI Classroom Films
results.brief_description: Provides a condensation of the individual Child Development films, and gives an overall view of Dr. Arnold Gesell’s work at the Yale Clinic of Child Development. Includes an introductory and concluding address by Dr. Gesell. Stresses the need for infant hygiene and discussed the various phases of infant behaviour.

results.title: Life at the top
results.creator_credit: Melissa Juhanson, Film Victoria and Victoria. Ministry of Housing and Construction
results.brief_description: Radiating from a dreary housing estate come the personalities of colourful individuals that have made their own worlds in a potentially depressing situation of high rise living in Australia. A multi-award winning film.

results.title: Life at the top
results.creator_credit: Pierre des Bonnet, Anne Boggan and United Nations
results.brief_description: A look at life in three highly industrialised countries in Europe: France, Romania and the United Kingdom, each of which seeks to further its national development goals through population planning. Focuses on the role of individual women, as influenced by their government’s policies, in determining family size.

results.title: Life at Salt Point: salt water ecology
results.brief_description: Salt Point, California is the setting for a broad survey of three marine ecosystems; the open sea, the wave-swept, and the tidal. The open-sea ecosystem focuses on a variety of planktonic inhabitants, their adaptations to a floating environment, and the marine food chain. The coastal ecosystems (wave-swept and tidal) show organism adaptation to varying water conditions, habitats within habitats, interaction within a species and interaction between species.

results.title: Life at Little Lon
results.creator_credit: Jo Lane, Ann Darrouzet, Jo Bell, Film Victoria and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: Presented by Robyn Williams, this documentary looks at Australia’s largest urban archaeological project, the excavation of an area known as Little Lon (Little Lonsdale Street). The excavations unearthed tens of thousands of artefacts and remnants of human history. The program also shows how archaeology can illuminate our understanding of places and times. Includes study notes on inside of slick.
